docs.abstract: Article in series The Fat Epidemic: An Extreme Solution focuses on bariatric surgery, major operation for massively obese people that simultaneously seals off most of stomach and rearranges small intestines to cut calories body can absorb; popularity of surgery mirrors rise in obesity and failure of diet, exercise and weight-loss drugs to help; painful and risky surgery, while producing large, lasting weight loss in majority of patients, forces patients to change their eating habits drastically, makes them violently ill if they overeat and puts them at lifelong risk for major nutritional deficiencies; diagrams; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: At a support-group meeting in June at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan, Lori Silverman proudly announced that in the last seven months she had lost 106 pounds. Ms. Silverman, 42, who used to weigh 306 and hopes to reach 120, won a round of applause. One by one, others reported similar victories: 140 pounds in four months, 85 pounds in seven months, 94 pounds in three months. And so on. More pounds lost, more clapping, more cheers -- testimonials from people who, thanks to steep weight losses, no longer needed medicine for diabetes, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, heartburn, gout or arthritis. Some had become able, for the first time in years, to fit into movie and airline seats, to reach down and tie their own shoes.

headline.main: Syndrome X and Its Dubious Distinction

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column report that condition known as insulin resistance is emerging as yet another risk factor threatening good health of one's heart; says doctors who focus too narrowly on serum cholesterol may be overlooking this potentially dangerous syndrome, as often happens with high homocysteine levels; concern about insulin resistance is mounting rapidly among cardiovascular specialists as two of its main causes--obesity, particularly abdominal obesity, and inactivity--also rise (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: A condition known as insulin resistance is emerging as yet another risk factor threatening the good health of your heart. And, doctors who focus too narrowly on serum cholesterol may be overlooking this potentially dangerous syndrome, as often happens with high homocysteine levels. Concern about insulin resistance is mounting rapidly among cardiovascular specialists as two of its main causes -- obesity, particularly abdominal obesity, and inactivity -- also rise.
